heading: 2.1 Introduction to Spatial Data
text: Spatial data describes location, shape, characteristics features Earth. essential fields like ecology geography, spatial relationships patterns analyzed. Spatial data can classified two main types:Vector Data: Represents discrete features points, lines, polygons.Raster Data: Represents continuous surfaces divided grid equally-sized cells pixels.data types commonly used together ecological studies model species distributions analyze environmental patterns.

heading: 2.2.1 Vector Data
text:
Vector data represents distinct objects defined boundaries. Examples include:Points: Locations, species sightings.Lines: Linear features, like rivers roads.Polygons: Areas, forests lakes.vector feature consists :
- Geometry: Specifies shape spatial position.
- Attributes: Provides information feature, species name elevation.

heading: 2.2.1.1 Example: Reading and Plotting Vector Data in R
text: Tip: Ensure files (.shp, .shx, .dbf) associated shapefile present loading R.
code:
# Load required packages
library(sp)
library(rgdal)

# Reading a shapefile
vector_data <- readOGR("path/to/shapefile.shp")

# Plotting the vector data
plot(vector_data, main = "Vector Data Example")

heading: 2.2.2 Raster Data
text: Raster data represents continuous phenomena temperature, elevation, land cover. comprises:Pixels: Grid cells, containing single value representing measured variable.Resolution: size pixel, determining level detail.

heading: 2.2.2.1 Example: Reading and Plotting Raster Data in R
text: Note: Higher resolution means smaller pixels detail larger file sizes longer processing times.
code:
# Load required package
library(raster)

# Reading a raster file
raster_data <- raster("path/to/raster.tif")

# Plotting the raster data
plot(raster_data, main = "Raster Data Example")

heading: 2.3 Coordinate Reference Systems (CRS)
text: coordinate reference system (CRS) defines spatial data relates locations Earth. ensures spatial layers align correctly mapped analyzed.

heading: 2.3.1 Types of CRS
text: Geographic CRS: Uses latitude longitude (e.g., WGS84).Projected CRS: Converts Earth’s 3D surface flat 2D plane, often used detailed regional analyses (e.g., UTM, Albers Equal Area).

heading: 2.3.2 Example: Reprojecting Data in R
text: Best Practice: Always ensure spatial layers use CRS analysis.
code:
# Reprojecting vector data
reprojected_vector <- spTransform(vector_data, CRS("+proj=utm +zone=33 +datum=WGS84"))

# Reprojecting raster data
reprojected_raster <- projectRaster(raster_data, crs = CRS("+proj=utm +zone=33 +datum=WGS84"))

heading: 2.4 Working with Spatial Data in R
text: Several R packages facilitate spatial data handling:sp: Widely used vector data (older).sf: Modern package simpler syntax.raster: raster data operations.terra: updated package designed replace raster, offering improved performance.

heading: 2.4.1 Example: Creating a Raster Stack
text: raster stack combines multiple raster layers single object analysis.
code:
# Creating a raster stack
raster_stack <- stack("path/to/raster1.tif", "path/to/raster2.tif")

# Plotting the raster stack
plot(raster_stack)

heading: 2.5 Aligning Resolution and Extent
text: working multiple rasters, crucial ensure :Consistent Resolution: pixel size across layers.Matching Extent: Identical spatial coverage.

heading: 2.5.1 Example: Resampling Rasters in R
text: Tip: Use resample resolution crop extend extent.
code:

heading: 2.6 Practical Exercise
text: Objective: Load process vector raster datasets species distribution modeling.

heading: 2.6.1 Steps:
text: Load vector dataset (species occurrences).Load raster datasets (environmental variables).Reproject vector data match CRS rasters.Create raster stack analysis.

heading: 2.6.2 Example Code
code:
# Load libraries
library(rgdal)
library(raster)

# Load vector data
species_data <- readOGR("path/to/species.shp")

# Load raster data
climate_raster <- stack("path/to/climate1.tif", "path/to/climate2.tif")

# Reproject vector data to match raster CRS
species_data <- spTransform(species_data, CRS(proj4string(climate_raster)))

# Plot results
plot(climate_raster)
plot(species_data, add = TRUE)
